And make each day a critic on the last.

Men must be taught as if you taught them not,
    And things unknown propos'd as things forgot.

The bookful blockhead, ignorantly read,
    With loads of learned lumber in his head.

Most authors steal their works, or buy;
    Garth did not write his own Dispensary.
For fools rush in where angels fear to tread.[325-2]
Led by the light of the Mæonian star.

Content if hence th' unlearn'd their wants may view,
    The learn'd reflect on what before they knew.[325-3]

What dire offence from amorous causes springs!
    What mighty contests rise from trivial things!
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto i. Line 1._

quotes.quote: And all Arabia breathes from yonder box.
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto i. Line 134._

quotes.quote:
On her white breast a sparkling cross she wore
    Which Jews might kiss, and infidels adore.
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto ii. Line 7._

quotes.quote:
If to her share some female errors fall,
    Look on her face, and you 'll forget them all.
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto ii. Line 17._

quotes.quote:
Fair tresses man's imperial race insnare,
    And beauty draws us with a single hair.[326-1]
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto ii. Line 27._

quotes.quote:
Here thou, great Anna! whom three realms obey,
    Dost sometimes counsel take--and sometimes tea.
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto iii. Line 7._

quotes.quote: At every word a reputation dies.
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto iii. Line 16._

quotes.quote:
The hungry judges soon the sentence sign,
    And wretches hang that jurymen may dine.
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto iii. Line 21._

quotes.quote:
Coffee, which makes the politician wise,
    And see through all things with his half-shut eyes.
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto iii. Line 117._

quotes.quote:
The meeting points the sacred hair dissever
    From the fair head, forever, and forever!
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto iii. Line 153._

quotes.quote:
Sir Plume, of amber snuff-box justly vain,
    And the nice conduct of a clouded cane.
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto iv. Line 123._

quotes.quote: Charms strike the sight, but merit wins the soul.
quotes.source: _The Rape of the Lock. Canto v. Line 34._

quotes.quote:
Shut, shut the door, good John! fatigued, I said;
    Tie up the knocker! say I 'm sick, I 'm dead.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 1._

quotes.quote:
Fire in each eye, and papers in each hand,
    They rave, recite, and madden round the land.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 5._

quotes.quote: E'en Sunday shines no Sabbath day to me.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 12._

quotes.quote:
Is there a parson much bemused in beer,
    A maudlin poetess, a rhyming peer,
    A clerk foredoom'd his father's soul to cross,
    Who pens a stanza when he should engross?
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 15._

quotes.quote:
Friend to my life, which did not you prolong,
    The world had wanted many an idle song.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 27._

quotes.quote: Obliged by hunger and request of friends.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 44._

quotes.quote:
Fired that the house rejects him, "'Sdeath! I 'll print it,
    And shame the fools."
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 61._

quotes.quote: No creature smarts so little as a fool.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 84._

quotes.quote:
Destroy his fib or sophistry--in vain!
    The creature 's at his dirty work again.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 91._

quotes.quote:
As yet a child, nor yet a fool to fame,
    I lisp'd in numbers, for the numbers came.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 127._

quotes.quote:
Pretty! in amber to observe the forms
    Of hairs, or straws, or dirt, or grubs, or worms![327-1]
    The things, we know, are neither rich nor rare,
    But wonder how the devil they got there.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 169._
_Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 186._

quotes.quote:
Should such a man, too fond to rule alone,
    Bear, like the Turk, no brother near the throne.[327-2]
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 197._

quotes.quote:
Damn with faint praise, assent with civil leer,
    And without sneering teach the rest to sneer;[327-3]
    Willing to wound, and yet afraid to strike,
    Just hint a fault, and hesitate dislike.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 201._

quotes.quote:
By flatterers besieg'd,
    And so obliging that he ne'er oblig'd;
    Like Cato, give his little senate laws,[327-4]
    And sit attentive to his own applause.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 207._

quotes.quote:
Who but must laugh, if such a man there be?
    Who would not weep, if Atticus were he?
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 213._

quotes.quote: "On wings of winds came flying all abroad."[327-5]
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 218._

quotes.quote:
Cursed be the verse, how well so e'er it flow,
    That tends to make one worthy man my foe.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 283._

quotes.quote:
Satire or sense, alas! can Sporus feel?
    Who breaks a butterfly upon a wheel?
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 307._

quotes.quote:
Eternal smiles his emptiness betray,
    As shallow streams run dimpling all the way.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 315._

quotes.quote: Wit that can creep, and pride that licks the dust.
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 333._

quotes.quote:
That not in fancy's maze he wander'd long,
    But stoop'd to truth, and moraliz'd his song.[328-1]
quotes.source: _Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 340._
_Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot. Prologue to the Satires. Line 408._

quotes.quote: Lord Fanny spins a thousand such a day.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Satire i. Book ii. Line 6._

quotes.quote:
Satire 's my weapon, but I 'm too discreet
    To run amuck, and tilt at all I meet.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Satire i. Book ii. Line 69._

quotes.quote:
But touch me, and no minister so sore;
    Whoe'er offends at some unlucky time
    Slides into verse, and hitches in a rhyme,
    Sacred to ridicule his whole life long,
    And the sad burden of some merry song.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Satire i. Book ii. Line 76._

quotes.quote: Bare the mean heart that lurks behind a star.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Satire i. Book ii. Line 110._

quotes.quote:
There St. John mingles with my friendly bowl,
    The feast of reason and the flow of soul.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Satire i. Book ii. Line 127._

quotes.quote:
For I, who hold sage Homer's rule the best,
    Welcome the coming, speed the going guest.[328-2]
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Satire ii. Book ii. Line 159._

quotes.quote:
Give me again my hollow tree,
    A crust of bread, and liberty.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Satire vi. Book ii. Line 220._

quotes.quote:
Do good by stealth, and blush to find it fame.

i. Line 136._


    To Berkeley every virtue under heaven.

_Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epilogue to the Satires. Dialogue
ii. Line 73._


    When the brisk minor pants for twenty-one.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book i. Line 38._

quotes.quote: He 's armed without that 's innocent within.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book i. Line 94._

quotes.quote:
Get place and wealth, if possible, with grace;
    If not, by any means get wealth and place.[329-1]

quotes.quote: Above all Greek, above all Roman fame.[329-2]
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 26._

quotes.quote: Authors, like coins, grow dear as they grow old.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 35._

quotes.quote: The mob of gentlemen who wrote with ease.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 108._

quotes.quote:
One simile that solitary shines
    In the dry desert of a thousand lines.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 111._

quotes.quote:

    And yielding, soft metal flow'd to human form.[329-3]

quotes.quote: Who says in verse what others say in prose.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 202._

quotes.quote:

    The varying verse, the full resounding line,
    The long majestic march, and energy divine.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 267._

quotes.quote:
E'en copious Dryden wanted or forgot
    The last and greatest art,--the art to blot.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 280._

quotes.quote:

    A breath revives him, or a breath o'erthrows.[329-4]
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 300._

quotes.quote:

quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 304._

quotes.quote: Praise undeserv'd is scandal in disguise.[330-1]
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle i. Book ii. Line 413._

quotes.quote:

    At last they steal us from ourselves away.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle ii. Book ii. Line 72._

quotes.quote: The vulgar boil, the learned roast, an egg.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle ii. Book ii. Line 85._

quotes.quote: Words that wise Bacon or brave Raleigh spoke.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Epistle ii. Book ii. Line 168._

quotes.quote:
Grac'd as thou art with all the power of words,
    So known, so honour'd at the House of Lords.[330-2]

Murray._


    Vain was the chief's the sage's pride!
    They had no poet, and they died.
quotes.source: _Satires, Epistles, and Odes of Horace. Odes. Book iv. Ode 9._

quotes.quote:
Nature and Nature's laws lay hid in night:
    God said, "Let Newton be!" and all was light.

Ye Gods! annihilate but space and time,
    And make two lovers happy.
quotes.source: _Martinus Scriblerus on the Art of Sinking in Poetry. Chap. xi._

quotes.quote:
O thou! whatever title please thine ear,
    Dean, Drapier, Bickerstaff, or Gulliver!
    Whether thou choose Cervantes' serious air,
    Or laugh and shake in Rabelais' easy-chair.

Poetic Justice, with her lifted scale,
    Where in nice balance truth with gold she weighs,
    And solid pudding against empty praise.

Now night descending, the proud scene was o'er,

While pensive poets painful vigils keep,
    Sleepless themselves to give their readers sleep.

Next o'er his books his eyes begin to roll,
    In pleasing memory of all he stole.

Or where the pictures for the page atone,
    And Quarles is sav'd by beauties not his own.

How index-learning turns no student pale,

And gentle Dulness ever loves a joke.
Another, yet the same.[331-1]

Till Peter's keys some christen'd Jove adorn,
    And Pan to Moses lends his pagan horn.
All crowd, who foremost shall be damn'd to fame.[331-2]

Silence, ye wolves! while Ralph to Cynthia howls,

And proud his mistress' order to perform,
    Rides in the whirlwind and directs the storm.[331-4]
A wit with dunces, and a dunce with wits.[331-5]
How sweet an Ovid, Murray was our boast!
The right divine of kings to govern wrong.

Stuff the head
    With all such reading as was never read:
    For thee explain a thing till all men doubt it,
    And write about it, goddess, and about it.

To happy convents bosom'd deep in vines,
    Where slumber abbots purple as their wines.

Led by my hand, he saunter'd Europe round,
    And gather'd every vice on Christian ground.
Judicious drank, and greatly daring din'd.

Stretch'd on the rack of a too easy chair,
    And heard thy everlasting yawn confess
    The pains and penalties of idleness.
E'en Palinurus nodded at the helm.

Religion blushing, veils her sacred fires,
    And unawares Morality expires.
    Nor public flame nor private dares to shine;
    Nor human spark is left, nor glimpse divine!
    Lo! thy dread empire Chaos is restor'd,
    Light dies before thy uncreating word;
    Thy hand, great Anarch, lets the curtain fall,
    And universal darkness buries all.

Heaven first taught letters for some wretch's aid,
    Some banish'd lover, or some captive maid.

Speed the soft intercourse from soul to soul,
    And waft a sigh from Indus to the Pole.
And truths divine came mended from that tongue.

Curse on all laws but those which love has made!
    Love, free as air at sight of human ties,
    Spreads his light wings, and in a moment flies.
And love the offender, yet detest the offence.[333-1]

How happy is the blameless vestal's lot!
    The world forgetting, by the world forgot.

One thought of thee puts all the pomp to flight;
    Priests, tapers, temples, swim before my sight.[333-2]

See my lips tremble and my eyeballs roll,
    Suck my last breath, and catch my flying soul.
He best can paint them who shall feel them most.[333-3]

Not chaos-like together crush'd and bruis'd,
    But as the world, harmoniously confus'd,
    Where order in variety we see,
    And where, though all things differ, all agree.
A mighty hunter, and his prey was man.
From old Belerium to the northern main.

Nor Fame I slight, nor for her favours call;
    She comes unlooked for if she comes at all.

Unblemish'd let me live, or die unknown;
    O grant an honest fame, or grant me none!

I am his Highness' dog at Kew;
    Pray tell me, sir, whose dog are you?

Father of all! in every age,
      In every clime adored,
    By saint, by savage, and by sage,
      Jehovah, Jove, or Lord.
Thou great First Cause, least understood.

And binding Nature fast in fate,
      Left free the human will.
And deal damnation round the land.

Teach me to feel another's woe,
      To hide the fault I see;
    That mercy I to others show,
      That mercy show to me.[334-2]

Happy the man whose wish and care
      A few paternal acres bound.

Thus let me live, unseen, unknown,
      Thus unlamented let me die;
    Steal from the world, and not a stone
      Tell where I lie.

Hark! they whisper; angels say,
    Sister spirit, come away!
quotes.source: _To the Memory of an Unfortunate Lady. Line 1._

quotes.quote:
Is there no bright reversion in the sky
    For those who greatly think, or bravely die?
quotes.source: _To the Memory of an Unfortunate Lady. Line 9._

quotes.quote: The glorious fault of angels and of gods.
quotes.source: _To the Memory of an Unfortunate Lady. Line 14._

quotes.quote:
So perish all, whose breast ne'er learn'd to glow
    For others' good, or melt at others' woe.[335-2]
quotes.source: _To the Memory of an Unfortunate Lady. Line 45._

quotes.quote:
By foreign hands thy dying eyes were clos'd,
    By foreign hands thy decent limbs compos'd,
    By foreign hands thy humble grave adorn'd,
    By strangers honoured, and by strangers mourn'd!
quotes.source: _To the Memory of an Unfortunate Lady. Line 51._

quotes.quote:
And bear about the mockery of woe
    To midnight dances and the public show.
quotes.source: _To the Memory of an Unfortunate Lady. Line 57._

quotes.quote:
How lov'd, how honour'd once avails thee not,
    To whom related, or by whom begot;
    A heap of dust alone remains of thee:
    'T is all thou art, and all the proud shall be!
quotes.source: _To the Memory of an Unfortunate Lady. Line 71._

quotes.quote:
Such were the notes thy once lov'd poet sung,
    Till death untimely stopp'd his tuneful tongue.

Who ne'er knew joy but friendship might divide,
    Or gave his father grief but when he died.
The saint sustain'd it, but the woman died.

Of manners gentle, of affections mild;
    In wit a man, simplicity a child.[335-3]

A brave man struggling in the storms of fate,
    And greatly falling with a falling state.
    While Cato gives his little senate laws,
    What bosom beats not in his country's cause?

The mouse that always trusts to one poor hole
    Can never be a mouse of any soul.[336-1]
quotes.source: _The Wife of Bath. Her Prologue. Line 298._

quotes.quote:
Love seldom haunts the breast where learning lies,
    And Venus sets ere Mercury can rise.
quotes.source: _The Wife of Bath. Her Prologue. Line 369._

quotes.quote:
You beat your pate, and fancy wit will come;
    Knock as you please, there 's nobody at home.[336-2]

For he lives twice who can at once employ
    The present well, and e'en the past enjoy.[336-3]
Who dared to love their country, and be poor.
Party is the madness of many for the gain of a few.[336-4]

I never knew any man in my life who could not bear another's
     misfortunes perfectly like a Christian.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book i. Line 1._

quotes.quote: The distant Trojans never injur'd me.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book i. Line 200._

quotes.quote: Words sweet as honey from his lips distill'd.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book i. Line 332._

quotes.quote:

    The stamp of fate, and sanction of the god.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book i. Line 684._

quotes.quote: And unextinguish'd laughter shakes the skies.[337-1]
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book i. Line 771._

quotes.quote: Thick as autumnal leaves or driving sand.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book ii. Line 970._

quotes.quote:
Chiefs who no more in bloody fights engage,
    But wise through time, and narrative with age,
    In summer-days like grasshoppers rejoice,--
    A bloodless race, that send a feeble voice.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book iii. Line 199._

quotes.quote: She moves a goddess, and she looks a queen.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book iii. Line 208._

quotes.quote:
Ajax the great . . .
    Himself a host.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book iii. Line 293._

quotes.quote: Plough the watery deep.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book iii. Line 357._

quotes.quote:
The day shall come, that great avenging day
    Which Troy's proud glories in the dust shall lay,
    When Priam's powers and Priam's self shall fall,
    And one prodigious ruin swallow all.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book iv. Line 196._

quotes.quote: First in the fight and every graceful deed.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book iv. Line 295._

quotes.quote: The first in banquets, but the last in fight.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book iv. Line 401._

quotes.quote: Gods! How the son degenerates from the sire!
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book iv. Line 451._

quotes.quote: With all its beauteous honours on its head.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book iv. Line 557._

quotes.quote: A wealthy priest, but rich without a fault.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book v. Line 16._

quotes.quote:
Not two strong men the enormous weight could raise,--
    Such men as live in these degenerate days.[337-2]
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book v. Line 371._

quotes.quote: Whose little body lodg'd a mighty mind.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book v. Line 999._

quotes.quote: He held his seat,--a friend to human race.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vi. Line 18._

quotes.quote:

    Now green in youth, now withering on the ground;[338-1]

    They fall successive, and successive rise.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vi. Line 181._

quotes.quote: Inflaming wine, pernicious to mankind.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vi. Line 330._

quotes.quote: If yet not lost to all the sense of shame.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vi. Line 350._

quotes.quote: 'T is man's to fight, but Heaven's to give success.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vi. Line 427._

quotes.quote: The young Astyanax, the hope of Troy.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vi. Line 467._

quotes.quote:
Yet while my Hector still survives, I see
    My father, mother, brethren, all, in thee.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vi. Line 544._

quotes.quote: Andromache! my soul's far better part.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vi. Line 624._

quotes.quote: He from whose lips divine persuasion flows.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vii. Line 143._

quotes.quote:

    And each brave foe was in his soul a friend.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vii. Line 364._

quotes.quote: I war not with the dead.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book vii. Line 485._

quotes.quote:
Aurora now, fair daughter of the dawn,
    Sprinkled with rosy light the dewy lawn.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book viii. Line 1._

quotes.quote:

    Beneath his helmet, drops upon his breast.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book viii. Line 371._

quotes.quote:
Who dares think one thing, and another tell,
    My heart detests him as the gates of hell.[338-2]
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book ix. Line 412._

quotes.quote:

    Not all Apollo's Pythian treasures hold,
    Or Troy once held, in peace and pride of sway,

quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book ix. Line 524._

quotes.quote: Short is my date, but deathless my renown.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book ix. Line 535._

quotes.quote:

    Sweeps the wide earth, and tramples o'er mankind.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book ix. Line 628._

quotes.quote:

    Burns with one love, with one resentment glows.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book ix. Line 725._

quotes.quote:

    And when Jove gave us life, he gave us woe.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book x. Line 78._

quotes.quote: Content to follow when we lead the way.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book x. Line 141._

quotes.quote: He serves me most who serves his country best.[339-1]
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book x. Line 201._

quotes.quote:

quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book x. Line 293._

quotes.quote: The rest were vulgar deaths, unknown to fame.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xi. Line 394._

quotes.quote:
Without a sign his sword the brave man draws,
    And asks no omen but his country's cause.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xii. Line 283._

quotes.quote:
The life which others pay let us bestow,
    And give to fame what we to nature owe.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xii. Line 393._

quotes.quote: And seem to walk on wings, and tread in air.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xiii. Line 106._

quotes.quote: The best of things beyond their measure cloy.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xiii. Line 795._

quotes.quote: To hide their ignominious heads in Troy.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xiv. Line 170._

quotes.quote:
Persuasive speech, and more persuasive sighs,
    Silence that spoke, and eloquence of eyes.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xiv. Line 251._

quotes.quote: Heroes as great have died, and yet shall fall.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xv. Line 157._

quotes.quote: And for our country 't is a bliss to die.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xv. Line 583._

quotes.quote: Like strength is felt from hope and from despair.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xv. Line 852._

quotes.quote: Two friends, two bodies with one soul inspir'd.[340-1]
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xvi. Line 267._

quotes.quote:
Dispel this cloud, the light of Heaven restore;
    Give me to see, and Ajax asks no more.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xvii. Line 730._

quotes.quote: The mildest manners, and the gentlest heart.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xvii. Line 756._

quotes.quote: In death a hero, as in life a friend!
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xvii. Line 758._

quotes.quote:
Patroclus, lov'd of all my martial train,
    Beyond mankind, beyond myself, is slain!
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xviii. Line 103._

quotes.quote: I live an idle burden to the ground.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xviii. Line 134._

quotes.quote: Ah, youth! forever dear, forever kind.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xix. Line 303._

quotes.quote:
Accept these grateful tears! for thee they flow,--
    For thee, that ever felt another's woe!
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xix. Line 319._

quotes.quote: Where'er he mov'd, the goddess shone before.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xx. Line 127._

quotes.quote: The matchless Ganymed, divinely fair.[340-2]
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xx. Line 278._

quotes.quote:
'T is fortune gives us birth,
    But Jove alone endues the soul with worth.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xx. Line 290._

quotes.quote:
Our business in the field of fight
    Is not to question, but to prove our might.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xx. Line 304._

quotes.quote:
A mass enormous! which in modern days
    No two of earth's degenerate sons could raise.[341-1]
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xx. Line 337._

quotes.quote: The bitter dregs of fortune's cup to drain.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 85._

quotes.quote: Who dies in youth and vigour, dies the best.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 100._

quotes.quote:
This, this is misery! the last, the worst
    That man can feel.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 106._

quotes.quote: No season now for calm familiar talk.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 169._

quotes.quote:
Jove lifts the golden balances that show
    The fates of mortal men, and things below.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 271._

quotes.quote: Achilles absent was Achilles still.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 418._

quotes.quote: Forever honour'd, and forever mourn'd.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 422._

quotes.quote: Unwept, unhonour'd, uninterr'd he lies![341-2]
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 484._

quotes.quote:
Grief tears his heart, and drives him to and fro
    In all the raging impotence of woe.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 526._

quotes.quote: Sinks my sad soul with sorrow to the grave.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxii. Line 543._

quotes.quote:
'T is true, 't is certain; man though dead retains
    Part of himself: the immortal mind remains.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxiii. Line 122._

quotes.quote: Base wealth preferring to eternal praise.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxiii. Line 368._

quotes.quote:
It is not strength, but art, obtains the prize,[341-3]
    And to be swift is less than to be wise.
    'T is more by art than force of num'rous strokes.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxiii. Line 383._

quotes.quote:
A green old age,[341-4] unconscious of decays,
    That proves the hero born in better days.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxiii. Line 929._

quotes.quote:
Two urns by Jove's high throne have ever stood,--
    The source of evil one, and one of good.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxiv. Line 663._

quotes.quote: The mildest manners with the bravest mind.
quotes.source: _The Iliad of Homer. Book xxiv. Line 963._

quotes.quote:
Fly, dotard, fly!
    With thy wise dreams and fables of the sky.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book ii. Line 207._

quotes.quote: And what he greatly thought, he nobly dar'd.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book ii. Line 312._

quotes.quote:
Few sons attain the praise
    Of their great sires, and most their sires disgrace.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book ii. Line 315._

quotes.quote: For never, never, wicked man was wise.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book ii. Line 320._

quotes.quote:
Urge him with truth to frame his fair replies;
    And sure he will: for Wisdom never lies.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iii. Line 25._

quotes.quote: The lot of man,--to suffer and to die.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iii. Line 117._

quotes.quote: A faultless body and a blameless mind.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iii. Line 138._

quotes.quote: The long historian of my country's woes.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iii. Line 142._
_The Odyssey of Homer. Book iii. Line 285._

quotes.quote:
When now Aurora, daughter of the dawn,
    With rosy lustre purpled o'er the lawn.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iii. Line 516._

quotes.quote: These riches are possess'd, but not enjoy'd!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 118._

quotes.quote: Mirror of constant faith, rever'd and mourn'd!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 229._

quotes.quote:
There with commutual zeal we both had strove
    In acts of dear benevolence and love:
    Brothers in peace, not rivals in command.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 241._

quotes.quote: The glory of a firm, capacious mind.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 262._

quotes.quote: Wise to resolve, and patient to perform.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 372._

quotes.quote:
The leader, mingling with the vulgar host,
    Is in the common mass of matter lost.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 397._

quotes.quote:
O thou, whose certain eye foresees
    The fix'd events of fate's remote decrees.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 627._

quotes.quote: Forget the brother, and resume the man.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 732._

quotes.quote: Gentle of speech, beneficent of mind.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 917._

quotes.quote: The people's parent, he protected all.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 921._

quotes.quote: The big round tear stands trembling in her eye.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 936._

quotes.quote: The windy satisfaction of the tongue.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book iv. Line 1092._

quotes.quote:
Heaven hears and pities hapless men like me,
    For sacred ev'n to gods is misery.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book v. Line 572._

quotes.quote: The bank he press'd, and gently kiss'd the ground.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book v. Line 596._

quotes.quote: A heaven of charms divine Nausicaa lay.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book vi. Line 22._

quotes.quote:
Jove weighs affairs of earth in dubious scales,
    And the good suffers while the bad prevails.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book vi. Line 229._

quotes.quote:
By Jove the stranger and the poor are sent,
    And what to those we give, to Jove is lent.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book vi. Line 247._

quotes.quote: A decent boldness ever meets with friends.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book vii. Line 67._

quotes.quote:
To heal divisions, to relieve th' opprest;
    In virtue rich; in blessing others, blest.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book vii. Line 95._

quotes.quote:
Oh, pity human woe!
    'T is what the happy to the unhappy owe.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book vii. Line 198._

quotes.quote: Whose well-taught mind the present age surpast.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book vii. Line 210._

quotes.quote:
For fate has wove the thread of life with pain,
    And twins ev'n from the birth are misery and man!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book vii. Line 263._

quotes.quote: In youth and beauty wisdom is but rare!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book vii. Line 379._

quotes.quote:
And every eye
    Gaz'd, as before some brother of the sky.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book viii. Line 17._

quotes.quote: Nor can one word be chang'd but for a worse.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book viii. Line 192._

quotes.quote: And unextinguish'd laughter shakes the sky.[344-1]
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book viii. Line 366._

quotes.quote:
Behold on wrong
    Swift vengeance waits; and art subdues the strong!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book viii. Line 367._

quotes.quote: A gen'rous heart repairs a sland'rous tongue.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book viii. Line 432._

quotes.quote:
Just are the ways of Heaven: from Heaven proceed
    The woes of man; Heaven doom'd the Greeks to bleed,--
    A theme of future song!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book viii. Line 631._

quotes.quote: Earth sounds my wisdom and high heaven my fame.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book ix. Line 20._

quotes.quote: Strong are her sons, though rocky are her shores.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book ix. Line 28._

quotes.quote: Lotus, the name; divine, nectareous juice!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book ix. Line 106._

quotes.quote: Respect us human, and relieve us poor.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book ix. Line 318._

quotes.quote: Rare gift! but oh what gift to fools avails!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book x. Line 29._

quotes.quote:
Our fruitless labours mourn,
    And only rich in barren fame return.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book x. Line 46._

quotes.quote: No more was seen the human form divine.[344-2]
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book x. Line 278._

quotes.quote: And not a man appears to tell their fate.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book x. Line 308._

quotes.quote:
Let him, oraculous, the end, the way,
    The turns of all thy future fate display.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book x. Line 642._

quotes.quote: Born but to banquet, and to drain the bowl.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book x. Line 662._

quotes.quote: Thin airy shoals of visionary ghosts.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 48._

quotes.quote: Who ne'er knew salt, or heard the billows roar.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 153._

quotes.quote:
Heav'd on Olympus tott'ring Ossa stood;
    On Ossa, Pelion nods with all his wood.[344-3]
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 387._

quotes.quote: The first in glory, as the first in place.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 441._

quotes.quote: Soft as some song divine thy story flows.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 458._

quotes.quote:
Oh woman, woman! when to ill thy mind
    Is bent, all hell contains no fouler fiend.[345-1]
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 531._

quotes.quote:
What mighty woes
    To thy imperial race from woman rose!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 541._

quotes.quote:
But sure the eye of time beholds no name
    So blest as thine in all the rolls of fame.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 591._

quotes.quote: And pines with thirst amidst a sea of waves.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 722._

quotes.quote: Up the high hill he heaves a huge round stone.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 736._

quotes.quote: There in the bright assemblies of the skies.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 745._

quotes.quote: Gloomy as night he stands.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xi. Line 749._

quotes.quote: All, soon or late, are doom'd that path to tread.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xii. Line 31._

quotes.quote: And what so tedious as a twice-told tale.[345-2]
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xii. Line 538._

quotes.quote:
He ceas'd; but left so pleasing on their ear
    His voice, that list'ning still they seem'd to hear.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xiii. Line 1._

quotes.quote: His native home deep imag'd in his soul.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xiii. Line 38._

quotes.quote:
And bear unmov'd the wrongs of base mankind,
    The last and hardest conquest of the mind.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xiii. Line 353._

quotes.quote: How prone to doubt, how cautious are the wise!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xiii. Line 375._

quotes.quote:
It never was our guise
    To slight the poor, or aught humane despise.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xiv. Line 65._

quotes.quote: The sex is ever to a soldier kind.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xiv. Line 246._

quotes.quote: Far from gay cities and the ways of men.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xiv. Line 410._

quotes.quote:
And wine can of their wits the wise beguile,
    Make the sage frolic, and the serious smile.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xiv. Line 520._

quotes.quote:
Who love too much, hate in the like extreme,
    And both the golden mean alike condemn.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xv. Line 79._

quotes.quote:
True friendship's laws are by this rule exprest,--
    Welcome the coming, speed the parting guest.[346-1]
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xv. Line 83._

quotes.quote: For too much rest itself becomes a pain.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xv. Line 429._

quotes.quote: Discourse, the sweeter banquet of the mind.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xv. Line 433._

quotes.quote:
And taste
    The melancholy joy of evils past:
    For he who much has suffer'd, much will know.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xv. Line 434._

quotes.quote: For love deceives the best of womankind.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xv. Line 463._

quotes.quote: And would'st thou evil for his good repay?
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xvi. Line 448._

quotes.quote:
Whatever day
    Makes man a slave, takes half his worth away.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xvii. Line 392._

quotes.quote:
In ev'ry sorrowing soul I pour'd delight,
    And poverty stood smiling in my sight.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xvii. Line 505._

quotes.quote:
Unbless'd thy hand, if in this low disguise
    Wander, perhaps, some inmate of the skies.[346-2]
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xvii. Line 576._

quotes.quote:
Know from the bounteous heaven all riches flow;
    And what man gives, the gods by man bestow.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xviii. Line 26._

quotes.quote:
Yet taught by time, my heart has learn'd to glow
    For others' good, and melt at others' woe.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xviii. Line 269._

quotes.quote: A winy vapour melting in a tear.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xix. Line 143._

quotes.quote:
But he whose inborn worth his acts commend,
    Of gentle soul, to human race a friend.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xix. Line 383._

quotes.quote: The fool of fate,--thy manufacture, man.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xx. Line 254._

quotes.quote: Impatient straight to flesh his virgin sword.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xx. Line 461._

quotes.quote: Dogs, ye have had your day!
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xxii. Line 41._

quotes.quote:
For dear to gods and men is sacred song.
    Self-taught I sing; by Heaven, and Heaven alone,
    The genuine seeds of poesy are sown.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xxii. Line 382._

quotes.quote: So ends the bloody business of the day.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xxii. Line 516._

quotes.quote:
And rest at last where souls unbodied dwell,
    In ever-flowing meads of Asphodel.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xxiv. Line 19._

quotes.quote:
The ruins of himself! now worn away
    With age, yet still majestic in decay.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xxiv. Line 271._

quotes.quote: And o'er the past Oblivion stretch her wing.
quotes.source: _The Odyssey of Homer. Book xxiv. Line 557._

quotes.quote:
Blessed is he who expects nothing, for he shall never be
     disappointed.[347-1]

quotes.quote:
So comes a reckoning when the banquet 's o'er,--
    The dreadful reckoning, and men smile no more.[348-1]
quotes.source: _The What d' ye call it. Act ii. Sc. 9._

quotes.quote:
'T is woman that seduces all mankind;
    By her we first were taught the wheedling arts.
Over the hills and far away.[348-2]
The fly that sips treacle is lost in the sweets.
Brother, brother! we are both in the wrong.
All in the Downs the fleet was moor'd.
Adieu, she cried, and waved her lily hand.
quotes.source: _Fables. Part i. The Shepherd and the Philosopher._

quotes.quote:
Whence is thy learning? Hath thy toil
    O'er books consum'd the midnight oil?[348-3]
quotes.source: _Fables. Part i. The Mother, the Nurse, and the Fairy._

quotes.quote: No author ever spar'd a brother.

Lest men suspect your tale untrue,
    Keep probability in view.
quotes.source: _Fables. Part i. The Painter who pleased Nobody and Everybody._

quotes.quote:
In ev'ry age and clime we see
    Two of a trade can never agree.[349-1]
quotes.source: _Fables. Part i. The Rat-catcher and Cats._

quotes.quote:
Is there no hope? the sick man said;
    The silent doctor shook his head.
quotes.source: _Fables. Part i. The Sick Man and the Angel._

quotes.quote: While there is life there 's hope, he cried.[349-2]

That raven on yon left-hand oak
    (Curse on his ill-betiding croak!)
      Bodes me no good.[349-3]
quotes.source: _Fables. Part i. The Farmer's Wife and the Raven._

quotes.quote:
And when a lady 's in the case,
    You know all other things give place.
quotes.source: _Fables. Part i. The Hare and many Friends._

quotes.quote:
Give me, kind Heaven, a private station,
    A mind serene for contemplation:
    Title and profit I resign;
    The post of honour shall be mine.[349-4]
quotes.source: _Fables. Part ii. The Vulture, the Sparrow, and other Birds._

quotes.quote: From wine what sudden friendship springs!
quotes.source: _Fables. Part ii. The Squire and his Cur._

quotes.quote:
Life is a jest, and all things show it;
    I thought so once, but now I know it.

quotes.quote: And we meet, with champagne and a chicken, at last.[350-2]

Be plain in dress, and sober in your diet;
    In short, my deary, kiss me, and be quiet.

Satire should, like a polished razor keen,
    Wound with a touch that 's scarcely felt or seen.
quotes.source: _To the Imitator of the First Satire of Horace. Book ii._

quotes.quote:
But the fruit that can fall without shaking
      Indeed is too mellow for me.

quotes.quote:
Take time enough: all other graces
    Will soon fill up their proper places.[351-1]

Some say, compar'd to Bononcini,
    That Mynheer Handel 's but a ninny;
    Others aver that he to Handel
    Is scarcely fit to hold a candle.
    Strange all this difference should be
    'Twixt Tweedledum and Tweedledee.
quotes.source: _On the Feuds between Handel and Bononcini._

quotes.quote:
[351-2]


    As clear as a whistle.
The point is plain as a pike-staff.[351-3]

Bone and Skin, two millers thin,
      Would starve us all, or near it;
    But be it known to Skin and Bone
      That Flesh and Blood can't bear it.

              Quæris Alcidæ parem?
    Nemo est nisi ipse

    (Do you seek Alcides' equal? None is, except himself).--SENECA:

JAMES BRAMSTON. ---- -1744.

    What 's not devoured by Time's devouring hand?
    Where 's Troy, and where 's the Maypole in the Strand?

_Art of Politics._


    But Titus said, with his uncommon sense,
    When the Exclusion Bill was in suspense:
    "I hear a lion in the lobby roar;
    Say, Mr. Speaker, shall we shut the door
    And keep him there, or shall we let him in
    To try if we can turn him out again?"[352-2]

_Art of Politics._

quotes.quote:
I knew once a very covetous, sordid fellow,[352-3] who used to
     say, "Take care of the pence, for the pounds will take care of
     themselves."
Sacrifice to the Graces.[353-1]

Manners must adorn knowledge, and smooth its way through the
     world. Like a great rough diamond, it may do very well in a
     closet by way of curiosity, and also for its intrinsic value.
Style is the dress of thoughts.
Despatch is the soul of business.
Chapter of accidents.[353-2]

I assisted at the birth of that most significant word
     "flirtation," which dropped from the most beautiful mouth in the
     world.

Unlike my subject now shall be my song;
    It shall be witty, and it sha'n't be long.

The dews of the evening most carefully shun,--
    Those tears of the sky for the loss of the sun.

The nation looked upon him as a deserter, and he shrunk into
     insignificancy and an earldom.

He adorned whatever subject he either spoke or wrote upon, by the
     most splendid eloquence.[353-3]

footnotes:
[352-3] W. Lowndes, Secretary of the Treasury in the reigns of
    King William, Queen Anne, and King George the Third.

    the Graces."--DIOGENES LAERTIUS: _Xenocrates, book iv. sect. 2._

    Seven Wise Men._ (A saying of Solon.)

[353-2] Chapter of accidents.--BURKE: _Notes for Speeches_
    (edition 1852), _vol. ii. p. 426._

    John Wilkes said that "the Chapter of Accidents is the longest
    chapter in the book."--SOUTHEY: _The Doctor, chap. cxviii._

[353-3]
    Who left scarcely any style of writing untouched,
    And touched nothing that he did not adorn.

    JOHNSON: _Epitaph on Goldsmith._


    Il embellit tout ce qu'il touche (He adorned whatever he
    touched).--FÉNELON: _Lettre sur les Occupations de l' Académie
    Française, sect. iv._

quotes.quote:
Thus I steer my bark, and sail
    On even keel, with gentle gale.

May see thee now, though late, redeem thy name,
    And glorify what else is damn'd to fame.[354-1]

footnotes: [354-1] See Pope, page 331.

quotes.quote:
The schoolboy, with his satchel in his hand,
    Whistling aloud to bear his courage up.[354-2]

Friendship! mysterious cement of the soul!
    Sweetener of life! and solder of society!

Of joys departed,
    Not to return, how painful the remembrance!

The cup goes round:
    And who so artful as to put it by!
    'T is long since Death had the majority.

The good he scorn'd
    Stalk'd off reluctant, like an ill-used ghost,
    Not to return; or if it did, in visits
    Like those of angels, short and far between.[355-1]

footnotes:
[354-2] See Dryden, page 277.

[355-1] See Norris, page 281.

quotes.quote:
Base Envy withers at another's joy,
    And hates that excellence it cannot reach.

But who can paint
    Like Nature? Can imagination boast,
    Amid its gay creation, hues like hers?

Amid the roses fierce Repentance rears
    Her snaky crest.

Delightful task! to rear the tender thought,
    To teach the young idea how to shoot.

An elegant sufficiency, content,
    Retirement, rural quiet, friendship, books,
    Ease and alternate labour, useful life,
    Progressive virtue, and approving Heaven!
The meek-ey'd Morn appears, mother of dews.
Falsely luxurious, will not man awake?

But yonder comes the powerful king of day,
    Rejoicing in the east.
Ships dim-discover'd dropping from the clouds.
And Mecca saddens at the long delay.

For many a day, and many a dreadful night,
    Incessant lab'ring round the stormy cape.
Sigh'd and look'd unutterable things.

A lucky chance, that oft decides the fate
    Of mighty monarchs.

So stands the statue that enchants the world,
    So bending tries to veil the matchless boast,
    The mingled beauties of exulting Greece.
Who stemm'd the torrent of a downward age.
Autumn nodding o'er the yellow plain.

Loveliness
    Needs not the foreign aid of ornament,
    But is when unadorn'd, adorn'd the most.[356-1]

He saw her charming, but he saw not half
    The charms her downcast modesty conceal'd.

For still the world prevail'd, and its dread laugh,
    Which scarce the firm philosopher can scorn.
See, Winter comes to rule the varied year.[356-2]
Cruel as death, and hungry as the grave.

There studious let me sit,
    And hold high converse with the mighty dead.
The kiss, snatch'd hasty from the sidelong maid.

These as they change, Almighty Father! these
    Are but the varied God. The rolling year
    Is full of Thee.
Shade, unperceiv'd, so softening into shade.
From seeming evil still educing good.
Come then, expressive silence, muse His praise.

A pleasing land of drowsyhed it was,
    Of dreams that wave before the half-shut eye;
    And of gay castles in the clouds that pass,
    Forever flushing round a summer sky:
    There eke the soft delights that witchingly
    Instil a wanton sweetness through the breast,
    And the calm pleasures always hover'd nigh;
    But whate'er smack'd of noyance or unrest
    Was far, far off expell'd from this delicious nest.
quotes.source: _The Castle of Indolence. Canto i. Stanza 6._

quotes.quote:
O fair undress, best dress! it checks no vein,
    But every flowing limb in pleasure drowns,
    And heightens ease with grace.
quotes.source: _The Castle of Indolence. Canto i. Stanza 26._

quotes.quote: Plac'd far amid the melancholy main.
quotes.source: _The Castle of Indolence. Canto i. Stanza 30._

quotes.quote: Scoundrel maxim.
quotes.source: _The Castle of Indolence. Canto i. Stanza 68._

quotes.quote: A little round, fat, oily man of God.
quotes.source: _The Castle of Indolence. Canto i. Stanza 69._

quotes.quote:
I care not, Fortune, what you me deny:
    You cannot rob me of free Nature's grace,
    You cannot shut the windows of the sky
    Through which Aurora shows her brightening face;
    You cannot bar my constant feet to trace
    The woods and lawns, by living stream, at eve:
    Let health my nerves and finer fibres brace,
    And I their toys to the great children leave:
    Of fancy, reason, virtue, naught can me bereave.
quotes.source: _The Castle of Indolence. Canto ii. Stanza 3._

quotes.quote:
Health is the vital principle of bliss,
    And exercise, of health.
quotes.source: _The Castle of Indolence. Canto ii. Stanza 55._

quotes.quote:
Forever, Fortune, wilt thou prove
    An unrelenting foe to love;
    And when we meet a mutual heart,
    Come in between and bid us part?

Whoe'er amidst the sons
    Of reason, valour, liberty, and virtue
    Displays distinguish'd merit, is a noble
    Of Nature's own creating.
O Sophonisba! Sophonisba, O![358-1]

When Britain first, at Heaven's command,
      Arose from out the azure main,
    This was the charter of her land,
      And guardian angels sung the strain:
    Rule, Britannia! Britannia rules the waves!
    Britons never shall be slaves.

footnotes:
[356-1] See Milton, page 234.

    Nam ut mulieres esse dicuntur nonnullæ inornatæ, quas id ipsum
    diceat, sic hæc subtilis oratio etiam incompta delectat (For as
    lack of adornment is said to become some women; so this subtle
    oration, though without embellishment, gives delight).--CICERO:
    _Orator, 23, 78._

    book iv. Winter Evening, line 34._

quotes.quote:
Ever charming, ever new,
    When will the landscape tire the view?

Disparting towers
    Trembling all precipitate down dash'd,
    Rattling around, loud thundering to the moon.

[359-1]


    Awake, my soul! stretch every nerve,
      And press with vigour on;
    A heavenly race demands thy zeal,
      And an immortal crown.
quotes.source: _Zeal and Vigour in the Christian Race._

footnotes:
[359-1] Dum vivimus vivamus (Let us live while we live).--ORTON:
    _Life of Doddridge._

quotes.quote:
Certainly this is a duty, not a sin. "Cleanliness is indeed next
     to godliness."[359-2]

footnotes:
[359-2] See Bacon, page 170.

[359-3] Given as a saying of Wesley, in the "Saturday Review,"
    Nov. 28, 1874.

quotes.quote: God helps them that help themselves.[360-1]

Dost thou love life? Then do not squander time, for that is the
     stuff life is made of.
Remember that time is money.

Idleness and pride tax with a heavier hand than kings and
     parliaments. If we can get rid of the former, we may easily bear
     the latter.

Here Skugg lies snug
    As a bug in a rug.[361-2]
There never was a good war or a bad peace.[361-3]

You and I were long friends: you are now my enemy, and I am
     yours.

We must all hang together, or assuredly we shall all hang
     separately.
quotes.source: _At the signing of the Declaration of Independence, July 4, 1776._

quotes.quote: He has paid dear, very dear, for his whistle.

Here you would know and enjoy what posterity will say of
     Washington. For a thousand leagues have nearly the same effect
     with a thousand years.

Our Constitution is in actual operation; everything appears to
     promise that it will last; but in this world nothing is certain
     but death and taxes.

footnotes:
[359-4] Eripuit coelo fulmen sceptrumque tyrannis (He snatched the

quotes.quote:
To be resign'd when ills betide,
    Patient when favours are deni'd,
      And pleas'd with favours given,--
    Dear Chloe, this is wisdom's part;
    This is that incense of the heart[362-1]
      Whose fragrance smells to heaven.
Yet still we hug the dear deceit.
Hold the fleet angel fast until he bless thee.

quotes.quote:
When I 'm not thank'd at all, I 'm thank'd enough;
    I 've done my duty, and I 've done no more.

quotes.quote: Thy modesty 's a candle to thy merit.

    And old England's roast beef!

quotes.quote: This story will not go down.

Can any man have a higher notion of the rule of right and the
     eternal fitness of things?
Distinction without a difference.
Amiable weakness.[364-1]
The dignity of history.[364-2]
Republic of letters.
Illustrious predecessors.[364-3]

footnotes:
[362-1] The incense of the heart may rise.--PIERPONT: _Every Place
    a Temple._

[363-1]
    Thus when a barber and a collier fight,
    The barber beats the luckless collier--white;
    The dusty collier heaves his ponderous sack,
    And big with vengeance beats the barber--black.
    In comes the brick-dust man, with grime o'erspread,
    And beats the collier and the barber--red:
    Black, red, and white in various clouds are tost,
    And in the dust they raise the combatants are lost.

    CHRISTOPHER SMART: _The Trip to Cambridge_ (on "Campbell's
    Specimens of the British Poets," vol. vi. p. 185).
